channel.title: Marvel Star Wars on jverkamp.com
channel.description: Recent content in Marvel Star Wars on jverkamp.com

item.title: The Ashes of Jedha
item.description:
Itâ€™s quite the story. A shattered planet with a truly giant hole down to the mantle. Another Force cult. (When you stare into the abyssâ€¦) Some new Imperial baddies.

This one has it all.

Got away from the series for a bit. This was a great place to pick it back up!

Onward.

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 6: Out Among the Stars
item.description:
STAR WARS #33-37 Annual #3

So many different stories in this one!

We have the beach episode.

A Lando Calrissian and Sana Starros team upâ€¦

â€¦double (triple? Quadruple?!) cross!

Han (with a weirdly photorealistic face) and Chewie transporting a Hutt:

And R2-D2 on a mission!

Iâ€™d â€¦ forgotten that C-3PO had gotten captured.

And if that wasnâ€™t enough, Scar Squadronâ€”and our favorite Storm Trooper with a lightsaber.

Thatâ€™s still weird to type.

I do enjoy the idea of a Storm Trooper just trying to do the right thingâ€”that doesnâ€™t actually join or even support the Rebellion. Itâ€™s a neat story we havenâ€™t gotten in the movies/TV (that Iâ€™ve seen).

Itâ€™s quite the mix and feels a bit disjoined, but I enjoyed it all well enough. I just was hoping for a bit more closure.

item.title: Star Wars: The Screaming Citadel
item.description:
Crossover!

With Doctor Aphraâ€¦ and Black Krrsantan? (And the droids of course).

That certainly has potential! Force Vampires! (of course thatâ€™s a thing) The titular â€œScreaming Citadelâ€â€”delightfully Gothic. Mind control brain crabs. Itâ€™s got it all!

Itâ€™s a little ridiculous at times and leans far more into the fantasy side of Star Wars, but I enjoyed it.

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 5: Yoda's Secret War
item.description:
C-3PO has been captured!

And Iâ€™m not sure whoâ€™s the worse off for it. ðŸ˜„

Itâ€™s not entirely clear if Darth Vader recognizes him or not. With as many memory wipes as C-3PO has apparently gone through, itâ€™s worth wondering if heâ€™s still even the same as he was when Anakin first built himâ€¦

But really, in an interesting sort of flip, most of this volume is the backstory! Andâ€”as might be hinted at by the titleâ€”we actually get pre-Prequel era Yoda! And Qui-Gon Jinn. Now I want to read more Qui-Gon Jinn stories. I wonder if thatâ€™s a thing.

Anyways, Yoda on a planet of feralâ€”and force sensitive because of courseâ€”children. Because of course thatâ€™s a story that has to be in the Star Wars canon. It actually gets far more interesting that I expected, but as Star Wars (outside of the movies) seems wont to doâ€¦ things get weird.

Itâ€™s a fascinating story, but again falls a bit into â€˜just how much did Luke do outside of the moviesâ€™ trap that just feels weird.

Onward!

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 4: Last Flight of the Harbinger
item.description:
Two main plots this time: good guys and bad guysâ€”itâ€™s all in your point of view and the Big Three steal something even bigger.

Itâ€™s fascinating how these stories at once seem smaller and more compactâ€”not able to stretch out on the big screenâ€”and at the same time tackle things the movies couldnâ€™t dare to approach in two hours.

Worth a read!

On a side note: how much or how little the artwork looks like Mark Hammill/Harrison Ford/Carrie Fisher varies widely, especially if you include issue covers.

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 3: Rebel Jail
item.description:
Backstory! Work Obi-Wan and Lukeâ€™s uncle. A prison hidden tucked right up against a sun. Hearding Nerfs. Sana, Leia, and Aphraâ€¦ working together?

Itâ€™s a decent enough adventure with quite the set pieces. I just wish I had more time in Obi-Wanâ€™s backstory now!

item.title: Vader Down
item.description:
And now things get complicatedâ€¦ Vader Down is a crossover between Star Wars (2015), Star Wars: Darth Vader (2015) and a single standalone issue. Itâ€™s a neat story, but out so I wish there were easier to read on Marvel Unlimitedâ€¦

Turns out Anakin can still flyâ€¦

Anyways, Vader is forced down. One thing leads to another and the Rebellion decides that an entire battalion might be needed to keep him down.

This may not be enough.

Itâ€™s nice to see Dr. Aphra again. Been a a bit. And oh the droids.

For as annoying as it is to switch from series to series, thatâ€™s quite an enjoyable story.

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 2: Showdown on the Smuggler's Moon
item.description:
The continuing in between adventures of all our original trilogy friends!

Itâ€™s a fun one, a dueling pair of adventures and a bit of backstory bridging the original trilogy and the prequels. I think thatâ€™d be an interesting era to read more about. How exactly did things go so badly so quickly.

item.title: Star Wars Vol. 1: Skywalker Strikes
item.description:
Let’s read another Marvel Star Wars series! This time, getting a bit away from Vadar, we have Star Wars (2015). Set (initially) right after A New Hope, we have the fallout of the (first) Death Star and the whole gang out on a variety of adventures!

Overall, it’s a fun start. I’m looking forward to seeing where they go from here!

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 7: Unbound Force
item.description:
Yeahâ€¦ no.

Just about stopped right thereâ€”not a huge fan of the Sabe plot line. It gets better though; untilâ€¦

The what now?

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 6: Return of the Handmaidens
item.description:
The Handmaidens. Hired to look like Padme; now theyâ€™re impersonating one another.

Good times. Silly names. But thatâ€™s Star Wars for you.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 5: The Shadow's Shadow
item.description:
Sabe!

It seems the Handmaidens freed a number of former slaves from Tattooine. Including some familiar very minor characters from episode 1.

A great way toâ€¦ blackmail Vader into doing a good thing?

For all Vader touts order over chaosâ€¦ he certainly does have a flair for shaking things up.

Also: an â€˜artificial life force draining stormâ€™ is so very Star Wars sounding.

Itâ€™s a fine story. Interesting to see the complexity Vader is struggling with even now/then.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 4: Crimson Reign
item.description:
All right.

So forget Luke and Han Vader is apparently going after this Crimson Dawn now.

Except:

Theyâ€™re everywhere.

Should be right up Vaderâ€™s alley.

Add to that the return of Sabe. Itâ€™s an unexpectedly interesting way to tie into Vaderâ€™s past. One just had to wonder if/when sheâ€™ll learn the truth of Vaderâ€™s identityâ€¦

Still not quite as good as the first two volumes but an enjoyable read nevertheless.

On thing I particularly enjoy about the comics is just how varied and alien the universe can feel:

Itâ€™s a nice contrast to how human centric the movies and shows have to be. Easier to draw a bug/lizard/ten foot ball droid than to put them on film.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 3: War of the Bounty Hunters
item.description:
Vader is after Solo nowâ€¦

With some interesting â€œalliesâ€.

Plus an appearance by the one and only (I assume) IG-88!

Coolest part:

Vader getting hacked sliced! Heâ€™s â€˜more machine now than manâ€™ so it fits. They could have done so much more with itâ€¦

The introduction (for me at least) of the Crimson Dawn is interesting as well. A Million Stronger than One. A neat idea to contrast the â€˜only two there areâ€™ Sith and the Big Damn Heroes of the Rebellion.

A bit more out there than the previous two volumes but I enjoyed it.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 2: Into the Fire
item.description:
Vader learned Luke was his sonâ€¦ and ran off across the Galaxy, tracking down anyone he could that might have hidden the truth from him.

The Emperor was not thrilled.

So he tears Vader apart over again, sends him back to Mustafar (planet of his both in a way), and forbids him the force.

Things only get more epic from here.

Itâ€™s a whirlwind of Vader passing test after trial, showing off just why heâ€™s one of the most powerful beings in the Galaxy. Until we return to Exegolâ€”2 years after the Rise of Skywalker; trying to fill in some of the mess that one made of continuity.

Vader is a weird choice for a protagonist, but likewise weirdly compelling. He is (at this point) unabashedly evil, yet I find myself rooting for him.

Worth a read.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 1: Dark Heart of the Sith
item.description:
Darth Vader, shortly after Luke escapes him in The Empire Strikes Back. Realizing that perhaps he doesnâ€™t actually know what happened to Padme.

Off to trawl through the past. Withâ€¦ quite the droid.

Itâ€™s a fascinating look into Vader forced to dig into Anakinâ€™s past. On Tattoine. Onâ€”and underâ€”Naboo. Work the Handmaidens and other from Padmeâ€™s life.

A fascinating mix. Iâ€™m curious where it goes next!

Side note: I canâ€™t imagine reading these issue by issueâ€¦ dang thatâ€™s a cliffhanger in issue 1â€¦

item.title: Dark Lord of the Sith, Vol. 4: Fortress Vader
item.description:
There’s a lot of interesting world building in this one, from a mask inhabited by a Sith Ghost (more or less; something we could use more of now that we know how often the Jedi do this), portals to a possible world beyond death, more hunting down Jedi, and Vader’s fortress–which I barely remember as a thing anyways.

It’s a solid volume, but not quite up to the level as what came before. Still worth a read.

item.title: Dark Lord of the Sith, Vol. 3: The Burning Seas
item.description:
Well that’s a fascinating addition. It takes what we’ve already been seeing– Vader solidifying his power in the time between Revenge of the Sith and A New Hope–and takes us to the Mon Cala system, home of Admiral Ackbar. And yes, it is in fact a trap.

It’s a fascinating way to expand a bit of the Star Wars universe I at least didn’t know much about, getting a bit of the tension between two different intelligent life forms on one planet (which I suppose we’ve also seen on Naboo) and fleshing out a race we’ve only seen a little about before. All from the point of view of our favorite black suited, heaving breathing menace.

item.title: Dark Lord of the Sith, Vol. 2: Legacy's End
item.description: Vader’s goal this time?

item.title: Dark Lord of the Sith, Vol. 1: Imperial Machine
item.description:
Another day… another Darth Vader serial?

Sure!

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 4: End of Games
item.description:
Okay. We’re heading towards the conclusion of this particular story arc. I really do like this length. 4 volumes has about as much oomph as a novel length story, albeit with a much higher concentration of pretty* pictures.

With that being said, Vader is making his way back into Palpatine’s good (bad?) graces–but he now truly understands how the Sith work.

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 3: The Shu-Torun War
item.description: Okay, now this went a bit sideways. Forget the Emperor and politicking (more or less). Instead, get thrown into a rivalry on a mining planet that’s obsessed with etiquette…

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 2: Shadows and Secrets
item.description:
More Vader! More Aphra!

More… trouble?

item.title: Darth Vader, Vol. 1: Vader
item.description:
Star Wars!

I’m of an age where I didn’t catch the original trilogy in theaters, instead watching it over and over again on VHS. When the prequels came out, I absolutely went to see them over and over in theaters (they’re not great, but they’re not as bad as they’ve been made out to be). Now more recently the new trilogy–well, I suppose I should finish those.
